note.p: Rufus Brown Bullock was a businessman originally from New York who served as a Confederate officer and governor of Georgia during the Reconstruction era.

Born on March 28, 1834, in Bethlehem, New York, Bullock graduated from Albion Academy in New York and became an expert in telegraphy. He began working for the American Telegraph Company in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, in 1855, then moved to Augusta, Georgia, to manage the Southern Express Company.

When the Civil War broke out in 1861, Bullock opposed secession, but remained in Georgia and accepted an officer’s commission in the Confederate army to operate telegraph and railroad lines. After the war ended, he became active in politics as a Republican and supported Black civil rights in Georgia. He was elected governor in 1868 and used his office to promote racial equality under the law. He faced stubborn, and sometimes violent, opposition by conservative whites and white supremacist groups like the Ku Klux Klan. Bullock frequently called for greater U.S. military enforcement of Reconstruction policies, in particular the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Amendments.

In 1870, facing severe criticism by white conservatives in Georgia, and following a significant Democratic victory in recent election, Bullock resigned his seat as governor and moved to New York. White supremacists in Georgia denounced him as corrupt, some calling him a “carpet bagger” (or northern opportunist who settled in the south during Reconstruction) despite his residency in Georgia since before the Civil War and his service to the Confederacy. In 1876, Bullock returned to Georgia and faced trial for corruption and fraud. He was found not guilty, which helped reestablish his reputation in the state.

Bullock lived in Atlanta during the last two decades of the nineteenth century, finding success as president of a cotton mill, as an executive in the English-American Loan Company, and through various positions in clubs and advisory boards in Atlanta and other parts of Georgia. He moved back to New York in 1903 and died there in 1907. Bullock was married to Marie Salisbury and had at least three children. He is buried in Mount Albion Cemetery in Albion, New York.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave; Russell Duncan, “Rufus Bullock,” New Georgia Encyclopedia)
Rufus Brown Bullock belonged to the following social groups:

Adelbert Ames served as a governor and U.S. senator of Mississippi during the Reconstruction era. He was born in East Thomaston (modern-day Rockland), Maine, in 1835. As a boy, Ames spent time working on various merchant vessels, receiving training in seamanship. He entered the United States Military Academy at West Point in 1856, graduating in May 1861, at the start of the Civil War. Commissioned as a second lieutenant, the young Ames was promoted to first lieutenant barely over a week later and served with the 5th U.S. Artillery during the battle of First Bull Run at Manassas, Virginia, on July 21, 1861. Despite being wounded in the leg, Ames stayed by his cannons. His actions at Bull Run led him to receive the brevet (honorary) rank of major and, in 1893 (more than thirty years later), the Medal of Honor.

Ames recovered from his wound and returned to the front lines in 1862, serving with distinction as an artillery officer during the Peninsula Campaign near Richmond. Seeking better promotion potential, Ames sought an infantry command. Through those efforts, in August 1862, he received command of the 20th Maine Infantry Regiment, and led that unit in combat during the Battle of Fredericksburg in December 1862. In May 1863, he volunteered to serve as a staff officer for Major General George G. Meade, which helped him achieve the rank of brigadier general that month. With this promotion, Ames left the 20th Maine to his second-in-command, Lieutenant Colonel Joshua Lawrence Chamberlain, who gained great fame commanding the regiment at Little Round Top during the Battle of Gettysburg in July 1863. Ames’ own performance at Gettysburg was highly praised, as his division successfully defended the Union position at Cemetery Hill.

After Gettysburg, Ames’ division was transferred to the Department of the South. Over the next two years, he commanded Union troops during campaigns in Florida, South Carolina, North Carolina, and Virginia. He received a brevet promotion to major general for his actions at Fort Fisher, North Carolina, in March 1865.

After the Civil War, Ames became involved in federal Reconstruction efforts. In 1868, he was appointed the provisional governor of Mississippi. Ames proved sympathetic to the plight of African Americans in the south. He sought to protect Black civil rights and appointed Mississippi’s first African American public officials. In 1870, after Mississippi was readmitted into the Union, Ames ran for U.S. senator for the state as a Republican and won. He served in that capacity from February 1870 to January 1874, achieving the reputation as a strong public speaker. While serving as a senator in Washington, D.C., Ames met and married Blanche Butler, daughter of Union general Benjamin F. Butler, under whom Ames had served during the war. Ames and his wife had six children over the course of their marriage.

In 1873, Ames ran for governor of Mississippi. His chief rival was James L. Alcorn, a former Confederate general who had been a Whig before the Civil War and joined the Republican Party afterwards. Ames won the election and worked diligently to improve Mississippi’s financial and social situation. In 1874, Democrats in Mississippi coordinated a campaign of violence against African Americans and white Republicans in the state, to secure political control in Mississippi. Unable to militarily suppress the white supremacist terror campaign, Ames signed a truce with Democratic leaders in Mississippi to reduce the violence and allow a peaceful election. Groups of white supremacists abandoned the truce and resumed their intimidation tactics against Republicans and Black Mississippians during the following elections, leading to a surge of Democratic politicians taking office.

In 1876, the conservative Democrat majority in the Mississippi legislature tried to impeach Ames and many other Republican officials with trumped up charges of corruption. Despite a strong political force against him, Ames’ critics were unable to provide any evidence of impropriety. Nevertheless, because impeachment was politically driven, Ames could see that his future as governor was over and any effort on his part to legally defend himself would be personally and financially taxing. He and his attorneys reached an agreement with Democratic leaders to resign his office in exchange for dropping the legal charges. On March 29, 1876, after Democrats cancelled their legal proceedings, Ames vacated his position.

Ames left Mississippi and went into business in Minnesota with his father and brother. A short time later, he relocated to New York City and then Massachusetts, overseeing mills and various business interests. When the Spanish-American War erupted in 1898, Ames volunteered for service and was appointed brigadier general of volunteers. Although over sixty years old, Ames joined the field campaign in Cuba and performed well.
Ames resumed his business ventures in the early twentieth century. He lived until 1933, dying at age 97. He is buried in Lowell, Massachusetts.
Adelbert Ames belonged to the following social groups:
Located in north Georgia, Cherokee County was established on December 26, 1831 from Hall and Habersham Counties. (New Georgia Encyclopedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

Currently located in Fulton County, Atlanta was founded in 1837 in what was then DeKalb County. When Fulton County was created on December 20, 1853, Atlanta became its county seat, and it became the capital of Georgia in 1868. (New Georgia Encyclopedia; Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

gloss.p: "The crime of taking something that does not belong to you, but not in a way that involves force or the threat of force." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The crime of illegally taking something that belongs to someone else." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The processing of individuals who have committed criminal acts." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A legal process in a law court where someone is accused of a particular crime and asked to say if they are guilty or not." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The act of using legal authority to catch and take someone to a place where the person may be accused of a crime." (CD)
"Having officially been found guilty of a crime in a law court." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The act of formally accusing someone of a serious crime." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"An occasion when someone is allowed to leave prison, etc." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who is in charge of a trial in a court and decides how a person who is guilty of a crime should be punished, or who makes decisions on legal matters." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A public officer who judges local and less important legal cases, and performs marriage ceremonies." (Cambridge Dictionary)

“Someone who works in an office, writing letters, making phone calls, and arranging meetings for a person or for an organization.” (Cambridge Dictionary) CWRGM includes people who perform administrative assistance under this tag, but we do not include government positions that incorporate the word secretary, such as Secretary of State, under this subject tag.

Operating at the state level, the Executive Department of State of Georgia was established in the Georgia Constitution of 1777. The department is headed by the Governor who is the head of the state government. The Governor is elected to a four-year term and is limited to two terms by the Georgia Constitution of 1983. To qualify for office, candidates must be at least 35 years of age, a United States citizen for at least 15 years, and a resident of Georgia for 15 years. (New Georgia Encyclopedia; Britannica; Wikipedia)

catDesc.term: Georgia--Office of the Secretary of State

gloss.p: Operating at the state level, the Office of the Secretary of State of Georgia was established in 1777. It is an office within the Executive Department and headed by the Secretary of State. The Secretary is responsible for keeping the state seal and flag, overseeing statewide elections, and managing public records. Until 1880 the Secretary was elected by the State Legislature but is now publicly elected and their term in office is four years. (New Georgia Encyclopedia; Wikipedia)

The term "fugitive from justice" is defined broadly and covers a multiplicity of experiences under U.S. law, but refers most often to "a person who is fleeing from custody, whether it be from jail, a government arrest, government or non-government questioning, vigilante violence, or outraged private individuals" (Wikipedia). Slightly different than the above definition, a fugitive from justice may also be defined as "a person formally charged with a crime or a convicted criminal whose punishment has not yet been determined or fully served who is currently beyond the custody or control" of the party, be it local, national, or international, interested in their arrest (Wikipedia). In the nineteenth-century United States, fugitive status varied widely based on race. Many white people considered "fugitives from justice" were most often the latter definition, being those charged with or convicted of crimes who then fled across other state lines to try and evade punishment or trial. However, throughout American history up to Emancipation, fugitive status was given to escaped enslaved African Americans under the Fugitive Slave Laws of 1793 and later 1850. These laws also required anyone in the nation to apprehend self-emancipated enslaved people and return them to their owners. The term "fugitives from justice" therefore became another legal mechanism by which enslavers sought to control the movements and freedoms of the enslaved, while contributing heavily to the increasing sectionalism that would lead to the American Civil War (Britannica). To learn more about enslaved people who emancipations themselves and were labeled fugitives, see the "Emancipation and self-emancipation" subject tag under Events.

element.label: Description
element.value: From the Mississippi Department of Archives and History Governor Ames Collection. Letter from Georgia Governor Rufus B. Bullock to Mississippi Governor Adelbert Ames, containing an extradition order for Enoch A. Rhodes for larceny. Also enclosed are affidavits from W. T. Harley testifying that Rhodes is guilty, sworn before Justice of the Peace J. E. Hutson; orders from Justice of the Peace John S. Barnes; and a certificate from Georgia Governor Bullock and Georgia Secretary of State David G. Cotting confirming that J. E. Hutson is a justice of the peace.

div.p: [seal]

State of Georgia.
RUFUS B. BULLOCK,
GOVERNOR OF SAID STATE,
TO HIS EXCELLENCY, THE GOVERNOR OF Mississippi

It Appears by the annexed papers, duly authenticated according to the Laws of this State, that Enoch A. Rhodes, stands charged with the offence of Simple Larceny com-mitted in the County of Cherokee on the 24th,, day of May 1868. and it has been represented to me that the said Enoch A. Rhodes fled from the justice of this State, and has taken refuge within the State of Mississippi.

Now, Therefore, Pursuant to the provisions of the Constitution and Laws of the United States, in such case made and provided, I do hereby request that the said Enoch A. Rhodes, fu-gitive as aforesaid, be delivered to Henry D. McConnell and Richard H. Baber or either of them who is duly authorized to receive and convey them to the State of Georgia, to be dealt with according to Law.

GIVEN UNDER MY HAND, and the Seal of the Executive Department, at the Capitol, in the City of Atlanta, the thirty first day of December, in the year of our Lord One Thousand Eight Hundred and Sixty-eight.
BY THE GOVERNOR:

B. B. de Groffenried
SECRETARY EXECUTIVE DEPARTMENT.

Rufus B Bullock
Governor
[seal]
[seal]

State of Georgia
Cherokee County

In person came before me a Justice of the peace for said county W T Worley who on oath saith that to the best of his Knowledge and belief Enoch A Rhoades is guilty of the crime of Simple larceny for that the Said Enoch A Rhoades in the state and county aforesaid did on or about the twenty fourth day of ^May^ in the year Eighteen ^hundred^ and Sixty eight unlawfully wrongfully feloneously privately and with intent to steal the same take and carry away from the possession of W T Worley one black horse Mule About three years old of the ^Value^ of one hundred and fifty dollars" and the personal property of the said W, T, Worley and opponent makes this affidavit that a warrant may issue for the arrest of the said Enoch A. Rhoades
Sworn to and subscribed before me this first day of Sept 1868
J E Hutson, J, P,
W. T Worley

State of Georgia
Cherokee County
To any Lawful officer to execute and return
W, T, Worley makes oath before me that on or about the twenty fourth day of May Eighteen hundred and sixty eight to the best of his Knowledge and belief Enoch, A, Rhoades

did in said county commit the crime of simple larceny for that the said Enoch A, Rhoades on or about the said twenty fourth of May Eighteen hundred and sixty eight in said County did unlawfully wrongfully feloniously privately and with intent to steal the same take and carry away from the possession of the said W. T. Worley one black horse mule about three years old of the value of one hundred and fifty dollars and being the personal property of the said W. T. Worley you are therefore commanded to arrest the boddy of the Said Enoch A Rhoades and bring him before me or some other Judicial officer of this State to be dealt with as the law directs You will also levy on a sufficiency of the property of the said Enoch A Rhoades to pay the Cost in the event of his final conviction

Herein fail not Given under my han^d^ and official Signature this the first day of Sept
1868
J E Hutson J P
September 5th 1868

State of Georgi
Cheroke County
The undersigned presiding as a court of Inquiry After hearing evidence as to the guilt of the Defendent in the within warrant decide and adjudge from the evidence adduced that the Defendent Enoch A Rhoades be bound over to the next term of the Superior Court of said county, And that he be committed to the Comm Gen'l of Said County, and there Safely kept until discharged by due Court of Law
John S Barnes J, P,

Georgia
Cheroke County
Ordered and adjudged by the court that W,, M, Beatie and Alfred Reece material witnesses for the state on the within warrant give Bond and good and sufficient Security for their personal appearance at the next Superior Court to held in said County to give Evidence then and there on and in behalf of the state to wit a Bond Each of five hundred dollars and as failure to give said Bond that they be committed to the common gen'l of the county there to remain until legally discharged
John S Barnes J. P.

State of Georgia
vs
E A Rhoades
(Simple Larceny)
J, E, Hutson JP
Executed the within by arresting the body of the defendant Enoch A Roads and arraigning him before the Court.
September 1st 1868
E, G, Gramling [?]

STATE OF GEORGIA,
BY His Excellency, RUFUS B. BULLOCK,
GOVERNOR OF SAID STATE.
TO ALL TO WHOM THESE PRESENTS SHALL COME:

Know Ye, THAT J. E. Hutson WHOSE OFFICIAL SIGNATURE APPEARS TO THE WITHIN INSTRUMENT, WAS, AT THE TIME OF AFFIXING THE SAME THERETO, a Justice of the Peace in the County of Cherokee, and State of Georgia WHICH APPEARS FROM THE RECORDS OF FILE IN THIS OFFICE—AND THAT THE SAME IS IN DUE FORM OF LAW:
Therefore, ALL DUE FAITH, CREDIT AND AUTHORITY ARE AND OUGHT TO BE HAD AND GIVEN TO his ATTESTATION AS SUCH.
In Testimony Whereof, I HAVE HEREUNTO SET MY HAND, AND CAUSED THE GREAT SEAL OF THE STATE TO BE AFFIXED.
Done at the Capitol, in Atlanta, THIS Thirty first DAY OF December, IN THE YEAR OF OUR LORD EIGHTEEN HUNDRED AND SIXTY-Eight
BY THE GOVERNOR:

David G. Cotting
SECRETARY OF STATE.

EXECUTIVE DEPARTMENT, GEORGIA,
ATLANTA, December 31st 1868

B. B. de Groffenried
SECRETARY EXECUTIVE DEPARTMENT.
Rufus B Bullock Governor
